author: hanskokx
body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I primarily use [Fluent Terminal](https://github.com/felixse/FluentTerminal/) (which, in my _humble_ opinion, is better than Windows Terminal. 🤷🏻‍♂️) In Fluent Terminal, I'm able to specify a powerline font, which looks lovely:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1911919/133313049-34b7d4dd-32cf-4d2c-ae6c-503481d257f3.png)

Unfortunately, I'm not able to specify a proper font when launching `pwsh.exe` directly, resulting in this monstrosity:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1911919/133313201-bb4a5d26-231a-40a3-83b6-4d8fc2c1e838.png)

I know the focus is on using Windows Terminal, in which I _can_ specify a powerline font... but can you _please_ add support to `pwsh.exe` for those rare instances in which I actually need to launch it directly? Pretty pwease?

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
This is really a conhost question which is what is being spawned by PowerShell/pwsh automatically when you start the executable. It has limited support for fonts and unicode characters outside the BMP which is what Windows Terminals really alleviates. I believe in later releases you can change the default terminal that a console application opens to Windows Terminal which would somewhat solve this issue when you open `pwsh.exe` directly. There's also something like https://github.com/Jaykul/PowerLine which you can try out which predates WT and gives a more PowerShell spin on the conhost side to get things working to an extent.

comments.author: hanskokx
comments.body:
I mean, you're about 12% correct. Yes, the issue is that conhost doesn't support fonts other than bitmap fonts.  Everything beyond that, you're technically correct, but it doesn't apply.

In fact, I don't _want_ to use Windows Terminal.  I prefer Fluent Terminal.  Still, every once in a great while, I need to launch pwsh.exe directly:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1911919/133336059-5a96bc0a-5331-4bb4-a2cc-e9c9033c73e0.png)

This launches the conhost, as you've correctly surmised.

My issue is this: conhost should allow more fonts than just bitmap fonts, because it's no longer 1998. :)

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
> My issue is this: conhost should allow more fonts than just bitmap fonts, because it's no longer 1998. :) That's the crux of the issue, it's a conhost problem, that may or may not have a future at all. Pwsh just uses conhost because that's the behaviour in Windows when a console process is spawned without a console supplied. Starting `powershell.exe`, `cmd.exe`, or any other console compiled application will behave in the exact same way and thus this problem isn't something specific to `pwsh.exe`. In saying all this, the link to the [PowerLine](https://github.com/Jaykul/PowerLine) module would potentially indicate it's possible to install the PowerLine font on conhost for use in PowerShell. Specifically see https://github.com/Jaykul/PowerLine#powerline-fonts-and-separators. I'm personally unsure how this is actually possible but potentially the fonts in question fit inside the BMP allowing it to be used in conhost. Edit: Reading online seems to indicate the PowerLine font glyphs cover codepoints inside BMP 0 (0x0000 - 0xFFFF) so just installing the font and selecting it should be enough. You can configure conhost for `pwsh.exe` to use a specific font or even have a shortcut to `pwsh.exe` with it's own specific font setting as well.

comments.author: hanskokx
comments.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1911919/133516823-50eb01cf-5881-44dc-ac2b-9f6f0071f5a7.png)

Tell me the font isn't installed. 🤷🏻‍♂️ The issue is that conhost doesn't support decent fonts.  I tried (unsuccessfully) to get the workaround going, but it seemed superfluous - especially since my font works in other terminal emulators.  Quite simply, the issue is with conhost.  I'm not saying that's the issue of PowerShell, but that doesn't mean it's not an issue.  Relying on additional software, be it Fluent Terminal, Windows Terminal, or otherwise, on top of the default install in order to support proper fonts seems a bit of a hack to me.

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
That's fair, I do remember reading something about conhost being selective around what fonts it can offer but even the current devs aren't 100% sure based on https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/issues/295.

Even so when I install the [nerdfont-hack](https://community.chocolatey.org/packages/nerdfont-hack) package with chocolatey I can see them as a selectable option in conhost

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8462645/133518259-f4988821-3b6a-4c82-94e9-1c59c7b94c3a.png)

Once I select one of the nerd fonts it is able to display in conhost

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8462645/133518951-c5539643-503a-4f60-a5c0-1cba6c8d1608.png)

You might need to ensure it's installed system wide and not just for the current user (no idea how to check that). Good luck in getting it working.
